name: Yoga Therapy
summary: A personalized application of yogic practices, including postures, breathwork, meditation, and lifestyle guidance, tailored to support physical, mental, and emotional health.
description: Yoga Therapy is an integrative healing approach that adapts traditional yoga practices to address specific health conditions and individual needs. Unlike general yoga classes, yoga therapy is tailored and therapeutic, often delivered one-on-one or in small groups by trained yoga therapists. Interventions may include physical postures (asanas), breathing techniques (pranayama), meditation, relaxation practices, and lifestyle recommendations. Evidence supports its effectiveness in managing chronic pain, stress, anxiety, depression, cardiovascular conditions, and rehabilitation support. Yoga Therapy is recognized as a complementary approach in integrative medicine and is increasingly incorporated in healthcare and rehabilitation settings.

treatment_duration: Ongoing for chronic conditions or wellness
metadata.training_required: Certified yoga therapist (C-IAYT or equivalent); additional healthcare background in some settings
metadata.regulatory_status: Recognized complementary health modality; certification regulated by organizations like IAYT

contraindications: Absolute: none inherent, but must adapt for acute injuries or medical contraindications
Relative: severe psychiatric instability, uncontrolled cardiovascular disease
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe when tailored by trained therapists; risks mainly from overexertion or unsuitable postures if not adapted.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong for stress, anxiety, and chronic pain; moderate for cardiovascular and rehabilitation applications.

sections.text: Yoga therapy integrates physical, respiratory, and mental practices to regulate autonomic balance, reduce inflammation, and enhance resilience. Postures improve mobility, strength, and circulation; breathing exercises (pranayama) improve oxygenation and autonomic regulation; meditation and mindfulness reduce stress and promote emotional balance. Psychophysiological pathways include reduced sympathetic activity, improved heart rate variability, and neuroendocrine modulation.

sections.preparation: Assessment of patient condition, goals, and limitations; development of individualized plan.
procedure: Guided asanas tailored to mobility and health status.
Breath regulation practices (e.g., alternate nostril breathing).
Lifestyle and self-care guidance (sleep, diet, stress management).
sections.frequency: 2–3 sessions per week plus home practice.
sections.total_treatment_time: 6–12 weeks for structured programs; longer for chronic conditions.

items: Integration with physical therapy or psychotherapy

immediate: Relaxation, reduced stress, increased body awareness
short_term: Improved mobility, reduced pain, better mood
long_term: Sustained stress resilience, improved physical health, enhanced quality of life

uncommon: Exacerbation of injuries if postures are not adapted
rare: Falls or strains in vulnerable individuals

special_considerations: Programs must be tailored to each individual’s medical history.

ideal_candidates: Individuals with chronic pain or stress-related conditions
Patients seeking integrative support alongside medical care
Older adults needing safe mobility practices
screening_required: Medical clearance for cardiovascular, respiratory, or musculoskeletal conditions

lifestyle_recommendations: Healthy sleep and stress management routines

sections.total_treatment_cost: Variable depending on program length; ongoing practice recommended
sections.insurance_coverage: Increasingly covered under integrative health or physical therapy programs in some regions

items: Yoga therapy differs from general yoga classes by tailoring practices to health conditions.
Evidence base is strongest for mental health and chronic pain conditions.
Yoga therapists often collaborate with healthcare professionals for integrative care.
Safety depends on appropriate adaptation for individual needs.
